<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 529, 92]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate pendulums. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 650, 123]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 1.1 and 1.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 138, 734, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 390, 321, 409]]<|/det|> **Fig. 1.1** <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 422, 423, 441]]<|/det|> A pendulum has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 453, 144, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 453, 875, 488]]<|/det|> Adjust the pendulum until its length \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\). The length \(l\) is measured to the centre of the bob. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 146, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 875, 551]]<|/det|> Displace the pendulum bob slightly from its vertical position and release it so that it swings. Measure and record in Table 1.1 the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations of the pendulum (see Fig. 1.2). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 144, 581]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 562, 875, 596]]<|/det|> Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 437, 626]]<|/det|> Record the value of \(T\) in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 146, 657]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 640, 865, 658]]<|/det|> Adjust the length of the pendulum until its length \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\). Repeat steps **(b)** and **(c)**. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 676, 517, 694]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 707, 688, 806]]<|/det|>
l/cmt/sT/s
30.0
60.0

The student plots a graph of \(l\) against \(T^2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 875, 384]]<|/det|> State two pieces of information from the graph that would indicate that \(l\) is directly proportional to \(T^2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 173, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 173, 445]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 444, 875, 462]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 146, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 875, 508]]<|/det|> Remove the pendulum and replace it with the other pendulum provided. <label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 808, 107]]<|/det|>
In this laboratory investigation, you will investigate the cooling of water by four methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 479, 137]]<|/det|>
You are provided with a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 430, 168]]<|/det|>
**Experiment A** (cooling with stirring).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 180, 180, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 875, 230]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into beaker 1. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops rising, record the temperature \(\theta_{1}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 240, 873, 260]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{1} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 272, 181, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 875, 307]]<|/det|>
Start the stopclock and stir the water for one minute. Record the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 319, 871, 339]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{2} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 350, 181, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 564, 369]]<|/det|>
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{1} - \theta_{2})\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 396, 873, 420]]<|/det|>
\[(\theta_{1} - \theta_{2}) = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 415, 875, 433]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 433, 465]]<|/det|>
**Experiment B** (cooling with pouring).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 144, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 476, 176, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 476, 875, 527]]<|/det|>
Empty beaker 1. Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into beaker 2. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops rising, record the temperature \(\theta_{3}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 537, 871, 558]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{3} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 570, 178, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 570, 873, 604]]<|/det|>
Remove the thermometer. Carefully pour the water from beaker 2 into beaker 1. Pour the water back into beaker 2. Repeat this process **four** times.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 610, 176, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 610, 875, 644]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. Record the temperature \(\theta_{4}\) of the water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 656, 871, 676]]<|/det|>
\[\theta_{4} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 688, 183, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 688, 567, 707]]<|/det|>
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{3} - \theta_{4})\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 736, 871, 757]]<|/det|>
\[(\theta_{3} - \theta_{4}) = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 753, 875, 771]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 784, 757, 803]]<|/det|>
**Experiment C** (cooling with a lid) and **Experiment D** (cooling without a lid).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 814, 144, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 814, 180, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 814, 368, 833]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 103, 433, 122]]<|/det|>
measure the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{g}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 358, 871, 378]]<|/det|>
\[(\theta_{5} - \theta_{7}) = \mathrm{......}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 390, 178, 410]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 390, 567, 410]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 435, 871, 456]]<|/det|>
\[(\theta_{6} - \theta_{8}) = \mathrm{......}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 453, 875, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 146, 503]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 483, 875, 518]]<|/det|>
Rank the experiments in order with the one that produced the greatest temperature drop first.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 528, 871, 549]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 668, 875, 702]]<|/det|>
If this laboratory investigation is to be repeated many times to check the results, suggest one condition that should be kept constant in order to provide reliable results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 631, 92]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 876, 139]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1 which shows the circuit that has been set up for you. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 135, 816, 358]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 367, 509, 386]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 556, 418]]<|/det|> You are provided with a length of resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 429, 144, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 429, 175, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 429, 875, 464]]<|/det|> Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) on the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(x\) from \(\mathbf{A}\), where \(x = 0.200 \text{m}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 469, 178, 488]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 469, 477, 488]]<|/det|> Record the value of \(x\) in Table 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 494, 178, 514]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 494, 875, 529]]<|/det|> Switch on. Measure the potential difference \(V\) across the wire between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\). Record the value of \(V\) in Table 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 535, 178, 554]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 535, 472, 554]]<|/det|> Measure the current \(I\) in the wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 549, 875, 570]]<|/det|>
I = .................................................... [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 581, 180, 600]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 581, 705, 600]]<|/det|> Take the sliding contact away from the wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) and switch off. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 611, 176, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 609, 870, 636]]<|/det|> Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the section \(\mathbf{AC}\) of the wire using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 636, 379, 655]]<|/det|> Record \(R\) in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 667, 517, 686]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 698, 838, 897]]<|/det|>
x/mV/VR/Î©
